c1_inversion_negative.title: Inversion with Negative Adverbials
c1_inversion_negative.subtitle: Adding emphasis by reversing subject and auxiliary verb.
c1_inversion_negative.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Inversion

1. Concept: Used for emphasis, mostly in formal English. We move the negative adverb to the start.

2. Structure:

Negative Adverb + Auxiliary + Subject + Verb

3. Common Adverbials: Never, Rarely, Seldom, Little, Under no circumstances, Not only... but also.

4. Examples:
Normal: "I have never seen such a thing."
Inverted: "Never have I seen such a thing."
✅ "Little did he know about the surprise."

explorer.original: I have never seen such beauty.
explorer.correctSentence: Never have I seen such beauty
Little did I know about it

scholar.original: You must not go there on any account.
scholar.correctSentence: On no account must you go there

scholar.original: He not only plays piano but also sings.
scholar.correctSentence: Not only does he play piano but also sings

scholar.original: I have never seen such a mess.
scholar.correctSentence: Never have I seen such a mess
Only then did I understand
Away ran the thief

scholar.original: I have rarely met such kindness.
scholar.correctSentence: Rarely have I met such kindness

scholar.original: She not only writes but also paints.
scholar.correctSentence: Not only does she write but also paints
Here comes the bus
Down fell the rain
Up went the balloon

specialist.original: Under no circumstances should you tell him.
specialist.correctSentence: Under no circumstances should you tell him

specialist.original: Not until I saw her did I remember.
specialist.correctSentence: Not until I saw her did I remember

specialist.original: Only by asking can you learn.
specialist.correctSentence: Only by asking can you learn

specialist.original: In no way is this true.
specialist.correctSentence: In no way is this true

specialist.original: At no time did he say that.
specialist.correctSentence: At no time did he say that

specialist.original: Only later did we find out.
specialist.correctSentence: Only later did we find out

specialist.original: On no condition shall you leave.
specialist.correctSentence: On no condition shall you leave

specialist.original: Not a single word did she say.
specialist.correctSentence: Not a single word did she say

specialist.original: Only in this way can we win.
specialist.correctSentence: Only in this way can we win

specialist.original: Little did they suspect the truth.
specialist.correctSentence: Little did they suspect the truth

master.original: Such was his power that all obeyed.
master.correctSentence: Such was his power that all obeyed

master.original: So angry was he that he shouted.
master.correctSentence: So angry was he that he shouted

master.original: Barely had I arrived when it started.
master.correctSentence: Barely had I arrived when it started

master.original: Were I you I would go.
master.correctSentence: Were I you I would go

master.original: Had I known I would have stayed.
master.correctSentence: Had I known I would have stayed
master.hint: Inversion for If I had known...

master.original: Should you see him tell him.
master.correctSentence: Should you see him tell him
master.hint: Inversion for If you should see...

master.original: No sooner had we sat than the bell rang.
master.correctSentence: No sooner had we sat than the bell rang

master.original: Only when I'm alone can I relax.
master.correctSentence: Only when I am alone can I relax
master.hint: Only when I am alone can...

master.original: Scarcely had the movie started when the power died.
master.correctSentence: Scarcely had the movie started when the power died

master.original: Not until midnight did they arrive.
master.correctSentence: Not until midnight did they arrive

c1_mixed_cond_past_pres.title: Mixed Conditionals (Past/Present)
c1_mixed_cond_past_pres.subtitle: Hypothetical Past causing a Present Result.
c1_mixed_cond_past_pres.quickLesson:
⚡ Mixed Cond 1

Structure: If + Past Perfect, ... would + Base Verb

Example: If I had slept, I would be awake.

explorer.original: If I (sleep) more, I would be awake.
explorer.correctSentence: If I had slept more I would be awake

explorer.original: If he (eat) breakfast, he wouldn't be hungry.
explorer.correctSentence: If he had eaten breakfast he wouldn't be hungry

explorer.original: If they (book) early, they would contain seats.
explorer.correctSentence: If they had booked early they would contain seats

explorer.original: If she (study), she would be ready.
explorer.correctSentence: If she had studied she would be ready

explorer.original: If I (not/lose) my key, I would be home.
explorer.correctSentence: If I had not lost my key I would be home
If you had asked you would know

explorer.original: If we (go) by car, we would be there.
explorer.correctSentence: If we had gone by car we would be there

explorer.original: If he (not/miss) the bus, he would be here.
explorer.correctSentence: If he had not missed the bus he would be here

explorer.original: If I (take) the pill, I would feel better.
explorer.correctSentence: If I had taken the pill I would feel better

explorer.original: If they (move), they would be happy.
explorer.correctSentence: If they had moved they would be happy

scholar.original: If he (accept) the offer, he would be rich.
scholar.correctSentence: If he had accepted the offer he would be rich

scholar.original: If I (not/spend) it, I would have money.
scholar.correctSentence: If I had not spent it I would have money

scholar.original: If she (win), she would be famous.
scholar.correctSentence: If she had won she would be famous

scholar.original: If we (plan), we wouldn't be lost.
scholar.correctSentence: If we had planned we wouldn't be lost

scholar.original: If I (finish), I would be free.
scholar.correctSentence: If I had finished I would be free
If he had listened he would know

scholar.original: If they (not/fight), they would be friends.
scholar.correctSentence: If they had not fought they would be friends

scholar.original: If I (wake) up, I wouldn't be late.
scholar.correctSentence: If I had woken up I wouldn't be late
If she had cooked we would eat

scholar.original: If you (call), I would be glad.
scholar.correctSentence: If you had called I would be glad

specialist.original: If I (invest), I would own a house.
specialist.correctSentence: If I had invested I would own a house

specialist.original: If he (train) harder, he would be champion.
specialist.correctSentence: If he had trained harder he would be champion

specialist.original: If we (save) water, we wouldn't be thirsty.
specialist.correctSentence: If we had saved water we wouldn't be thirsty

specialist.original: If they (not/break) it, it would work.
specialist.correctSentence: If they had not broken it it would work

specialist.original: If I (read) it, I would know the answer.
specialist.correctSentence: If I had read it I would know the answer

specialist.original: If she (apply), she would have the job.
specialist.correctSentence: If she had applied she would have the job

specialist.original: If you (warn) me, I would be safe.
specialist.correctSentence: If you had warned me I would be safe

specialist.original: If he (fix) the car, we would be driving.
specialist.correctSentence: If he had fixed the car we would be driving

specialist.original: If I (keep) the receipt, I could return it.
specialist.correctSentence: If I had kept the receipt I could return it

specialist.original: If they (bring) food, we wouldn't be starving.
specialist.correctSentence: If they had brought food we wouldn't be starving

master.original: Had I studied, I would be a doctor.
master.correctSentence: Had I studied I would be a doctor

master.original: Had he not lied, he would be trusted.
master.correctSentence: Had he not lied he would be trusted

master.original: Had they left, they would be clear.
master.correctSentence: Had they left they would be clear

master.original: Had she practiced, she would be winning.
master.correctSentence: Had she practiced she would be winning

master.original: Had we bought it, we would have it.
master.correctSentence: Had we bought it we would have it

master.original: Had I known, I would not be here.
master.correctSentence: Had I known I would not be here

master.original: Had you helped, it would be done.
master.correctSentence: Had you helped it would be done

master.original: Had it rained, the grass would be wet.
master.correctSentence: Had it rained the grass would be wet

master.original: Had they paid, they would allow it.
master.correctSentence: Had they paid they would allow it

master.original: Had I seen, I would believe.
master.correctSentence: Had I seen I would believe

c1_mixed_cond_pres_past.title: Mixed Conditionals (Present/Past)
c1_mixed_cond_pres_past.subtitle: Present Condition causing a Past Result.
c1_mixed_cond_pres_past.quickLesson:
⚡ Mixed Cond 2

Structure: If + Past Simple, ... would have + Past Participle

Example: If I were taller, I would have played basketball.

explorer.original: If I (be) rich, I would have bought it.
explorer.correctSentence: If I were rich I would have bought it
explorer.hint: If I were... would have bought

explorer.original: If he (be) smart, he wouldn't have done it.
explorer.correctSentence: If he were smart he wouldn't have done it

explorer.original: If she (know) French, she would have translated.
explorer.correctSentence: If she knew French she would have translated

explorer.original: If I (have) time, I would have gone.
explorer.correctSentence: If I had time I would have gone

explorer.original: If they (be) here, they would have helped.
explorer.correctSentence: If they were here they would have helped

explorer.original: If you (like) spicy food, you would have eaten it.
explorer.correctSentence: If you liked spicy food you would have eaten it

explorer.original: If I (not/be) tired, I would have come.
explorer.correctSentence: If I weren't tired I would have come

explorer.original: If he (be) honest, he would have told the truth.
explorer.correctSentence: If he were honest he would have told the truth

explorer.original: If we (live) near, we would have visited.
explorer.correctSentence: If we lived near we would have visited

explorer.original: If it (be) easy, I would have finished.
explorer.correctSentence: If it were easy I would have finished

scholar.original: If he (be) a pro, he would have won.
scholar.correctSentence: If he were a pro he would have won
scholar.hint: Were a pro... would have won

scholar.original: If I (own) a car, I would have driven.
scholar.correctSentence: If I owned a car I would have driven

scholar.original: If they (not/be) lazy, they would have passed.
scholar.correctSentence: If they weren't lazy they would have passed

scholar.original: If she (love) him, she wouldn't have left.
scholar.correctSentence: If she loved him she wouldn't have left

scholar.original: If we (know) the city, we wouldn't have gotten lost.
scholar.correctSentence: If we knew the city we wouldn't have gotten lost

scholar.original: If you (be) taller, you could have reached it.
scholar.correctSentence: If you were taller you could have reached it

scholar.original: If he (speak) Spanish, he would have understood.
scholar.correctSentence: If he spoke Spanish he would have understood

scholar.original: If I (not/have) work, I would have joined.
scholar.correctSentence: If I didn't have work I would have joined

scholar.original: If they (be) rich, they would have traveled.
scholar.correctSentence: If they were rich they would have traveled

scholar.original: If she (be) single, I would have asked her out.
scholar.correctSentence: If she were single I would have asked her out

specialist.original: If I (be) you, I would have accepted.
specialist.correctSentence: If I were you I would have accepted

specialist.original: If he (not/be) afraid, he would have jumped.
specialist.correctSentence: If he weren't afraid he would have jumped

specialist.original: If they (trust) us, they would have invested.
specialist.correctSentence: If they trusted us they would have invested

specialist.original: If it (not/be) cold, we would have swum.
specialist.correctSentence: If it weren't cold we would have swum

specialist.original: If I (be) smarter, I would have solved it.
specialist.correctSentence: If I were smarter I would have solved it

specialist.original: If she (have) patience, she would have waited.
specialist.correctSentence: If she had patience she would have waited

specialist.original: If we (like) jazz, we would have gone.
specialist.correctSentence: If we liked jazz we would have gone

specialist.original: If he (be) leader, things would have changed.
specialist.correctSentence: If he were leader things would have changed

specialist.original: If I (not/know) him, I wouldn't have let him in.
specialist.correctSentence: If I didn't know him I wouldn't have let him in

specialist.original: If they (be) qualified, they would have been hired.
specialist.correctSentence: If they were qualified they would have been hired
specialist.hint: Were qualified... would have been hired

master.original: Were I brave, I would have fought.
master.correctSentence: Were I brave I would have fought

master.original: Were he wise, he would have refused.
master.correctSentence: Were he wise he would have refused

master.original: Were she ready, she would have started.
master.correctSentence: Were she ready she would have started

master.original: Were they honest, they would have confessed.
master.correctSentence: Were they honest they would have confessed

master.original: Were it simple, I would have done it.
master.correctSentence: Were it simple I would have done it

master.original: Were I not busy, I would have helped.
master.correctSentence: Were I not busy I would have helped

master.original: Were he not ill, he would have come.
master.correctSentence: Were he not ill he would have come

master.original: Were we not friends, I would have sued.
master.correctSentence: Were we not friends I would have sued

master.original: Were it not late, I would have stayed.
master.correctSentence: Were it not late I would have stayed

master.original: Were you kinder, you would have forgiven.
master.correctSentence: Were you kinder you would have forgiven

c1_cleft_sentences.title: Cleft Sentences
c1_cleft_sentences.subtitle: Focusing on specific parts of a sentence.
c1_cleft_sentences.quickLesson:
⚡ Cleft Sentences

1. 'It' Clefts: It was [John] who called me.

2. 'Wh-' Clefts: [What I need] is a break.

explorer.correctSentence: It was John who called me
What I need is a coffee
It is jazz that she likes
It was he who broke the window
It was a bear that they saw
What I lost was my phone
It was Mary who cooked dinner
It is pizza that I love

scholar.correctSentence: It was the noise that woke me up
What I requested was a refund
It was Tom who made the mistake
What she wants is respect
It is the heat that bothers me
What I enjoyed was the music
It was he who fixed the roof
What they need is money
It was speed that caused the crash
What I fear are spiders

specialist.correctSentence: All I asked for was help

specialist.original: She only wants to be happy.
specialist.correctSentence: All she wants is to be happy
It was yesterday that I arrived

specialist.original: He is looking for his keys.
specialist.correctSentence: It is his keys that he is looking for
What I didn't say was that
It was the painting that they stole
All he does is sleep
It is her smile that I love
What we need is more time
It was the weather that ruined the trip

master.original: I did it because I care.
master.correctSentence: The reason why I did it was because I care
It was due to stress that she resigned
What he wants is to be heard
It was in Paris that they met
It is her courage that I admire
What happened was that the car broke down
It is hard work that success necessitates
What I dislike is his arrogance

master.original: She solved the problem by herself.
master.correctSentence: It was by herself that she solved the problem

master.original: We are waiting for the doctor.
master.correctSentence: The person we are waiting for is the doctor

c1_advanced_passive.title: Advanced Passive
c1_advanced_passive.subtitle: Impersonal structures and reporting verbs.
c1_advanced_passive.quickLesson:
⚡ Advanced Passive

1. It is said that... (It is said that he is rich)

2. He is said to be... (He is said to be rich)

explorer.correctSentence: It is said that he is rich

explorer.original: They believe she is a genius.
explorer.correctSentence: It is believed that she is a genius
It is expected that it will rain soon
It is thought that he lied
It is reported that the war ended
It is known that smoking is bad

explorer.original: They say money cannot buy love.
explorer.correctSentence: It is said that money cannot buy love
It is hoped that he recovers
It is alleged that he stole it
It is considered that he is a hero

scholar.correctSentence: He is said to be rich
She is believed to be working
He is thought to live here
The boss is reported to have arrived
scholar.hint: The boss is reported to have...

scholar.original: We expect the train to be late.
scholar.correctSentence: The train is expected to be late

scholar.original: They say he was a spy.
scholar.correctSentence: He is said to have been a spy
scholar.hint: He is said to have been...

scholar.correctSentence: She is considered to be a leader

scholar.original: They know the earth is round.
scholar.correctSentence: The earth is known to be round
scholar.hint: The earth is known to be...

scholar.original: We allege he stole the car.
scholar.correctSentence: He is alleged to have stolen the car
scholar.hint: He is alleged to have stolen...

scholar.correctSentence: He is understood to be busy

specialist.original: People judged him to cover up.
specialist.correctSentence: He was judged to execute a cover up
He was presumed to be dead
The cost was estimated to be $50

specialist.original: They intended the law for safety.
specialist.correctSentence: The law was intended for safety

specialist.original: People felt the decision was wrong.
specialist.correctSentence: The decision was felt to be wrong
The meeting was declared open
The task was found to be hard
specialist.hint: The task was found to be...

specialist.correctSentence: He was seen to leave
She was heard to sing
He was made to confess

master.original: There is a rumor he quit.
master.correctSentence: He is rumored to have quit
It is assumed that he is guilty

master.original: We claim she is the best.
master.correctSentence: She is claimed to be the best
It is deemed necessary
He is acknowledged to be right
Innocence is presumed
He is held responsible

master.original: We perceive the risk as high.
master.correctSentence: The risk is perceived as high

master.original: They regard him as a genius.
master.correctSentence: He is regarded as a genius
It is implied that he cheated

c1_passive_get_have.title: Causative Passive
c1_passive_get_have.subtitle: Having or getting something done by someone else.
c1_passive_get_have.quickLesson:
⚡ Causative

1. Have/Get something done: I had my car fixed.

2. Have someone do: I had him fix it.

3. Get someone to do: I got him to fix it.

explorer.original: I paid a mechanic to fix my car.
She asked a barber to cut her hair.
We employed a painter for the house.
He paid someone to wash the windows.
I will tell the cleaner to clean this.

explorer.correctSentence: She is getting her watch fixed
They will have the photos printed

explorer.original: I need to check my eyes.
explorer.correctSentence: I need to have my eyes checked
explorer.hint: I need to have my eyes...

explorer.correctSentence: We must get the roof repaired

scholar.correctSentence: I got him to go
She had him help
We got them to stay

scholar.original: He told the mechanic to check the oil.
scholar.correctSentence: He had the mechanic check the oil
They got me to talk
I had her call
We got John to join

scholar.original: She requested the maid to clean.
scholar.correctSentence: She had the maid clean
He got us to try
I had him wait

specialist.correctSentence: I had my bike stolen

specialist.original: His nose was broken in a fight.
specialist.correctSentence: He had his nose broken in a fight
She got her passport stolen
We got ourselves fired
They got arrested
I got invited
The car got damaged
I had my bag checked
She had her application rejected
We got delayed

master.correctSentence: Please get this fixed immediately

master.original: I want you to explain this.
master.correctSentence: I want to have this explained
Get it done
Have the facts established
Have him removed
Get the data analyzed
Get the contract signed
Have the files organized
Have the email sent
Get the issue solved

c1_future_in_past.title: Future in the Past
c1_future_in_past.subtitle: Talking about the future from a past perspective.
c1_future_in_past.quickLesson:
⚡ Future in the Past

1. Was/Were going to: Plans that didn't happen.

2. Would: Future events from a past viewpoint.

3. Was/Were to have + PP: Unfulfilled plans.

explorer.correctSentence: I was going to call you
We were going to leave early

explorer.original: He knew he had a meeting.
explorer.correctSentence: He knew he would have a meeting

explorer.original: It was nearly time to go.

explorer.correctSentence: She was going to tell you
We were going to have a party

explorer.original: He was on the verge of crying.

scholar.correctSentence: The meeting was to take place at 5

scholar.original: She was meant to arrive yesterday.
scholar.correctSentence: She was to have arrived yesterday
We were on the point of leaving

scholar.original: He didn't know he would fail.
scholar.correctSentence: Little did he know he would fail
They were to meet later
I was about to speak
She was going to write
We thought we would succeed

scholar.original: The plan was to start now.
scholar.correctSentence: We were to have started now
He was on the verge of death

specialist.correctSentence: The concert was to have taken place
They were never to meet again
I was on the brink of quitting
She was to become queen
He was meaning to escape
We were just about to miss you
I was hoping to help
They were to regret it
It was about to end

specialist.original: We planned a trip but failed.
specialist.correctSentence: We were to have gone on a trip

master.correctSentence: He was later to win

master.original: A discovery was made years later.
master.correctSentence: It was to be years before the discovery
I was on the verge of saying it
They were not to sell it
He was destined to be rich
We were within an ace of forgetting
She was to have caught the bus
It was to be a disaster
I had intended to resign
They were about to finish

c1_modals_deduction_past.title: Modals of Deduction (Past)
c1_modals_deduction_past.subtitle: Speculating about past events.
c1_modals_deduction_past.quickLesson:
⚡ Modals in Past

1. Must have + PP: 99% sure it happened.

2. Can't/Couldn't have + PP: 99% sure it didn't happen.

3. Might/May/Could have + PP: Maybe (50%).

scholar.correctSentence: She must have arrived
He couldn't have finished
They might have missed the bus
It must have been hard
He could have been sleeping
She can't have said that
He must have forgotten
I might have made a mistake
They must have seen us
He couldn't have known

specialist.original: I'm certain the cat took it.
specialist.correctSentence: The cat must have taken it

specialist.original: Maybe the alarm didn't go off.
specialist.correctSentence: The alarm might not have gone off

specialist.original: I am sure you were tired.
specialist.correctSentence: You must have been tired
She couldn't have walked there
He may have been joking
They must have had a reason

specialist.original: It's impossible you saw a ghost.
specialist.correctSentence: You can't have seen a ghost
She might not have heard
He must have cooked
They could have been lost

master.correctSentence: He must have realized his mistake

master.original: Impossible that he did it alone.
master.correctSentence: He can't have done it alone
It might have been a misunderstanding
They must have left early
She may have forgotten
He can't have meant it
It must have been him
They could have missed the flight
She couldn't have failed
You must have helped

c1_advanced_gerunds.title: Advanced Gerunds & Infinitives
c1_advanced_gerunds.subtitle: Complex patterns with gerunds and infinitives.
c1_advanced_gerunds.quickLesson:
⚡ Advanced Gerunds/Infinitives

1. Perfect Infinitive: to have done

2. Perfect Gerund: having done

3. Passive Forms: to be done / being done

explorer.correctSentence: I am happy to have finished

explorer.original: It is nice to meet you.
explorer.correctSentence: It is nice to have met you

scholar.correctSentence: I recall him having said that
She seems to have understood
I appreciate your having helped
He is proud to have won
We look forward to meeting
It's no use crying
I can't help laughing
She denied seeing him
He pretends to be rich
I happen to have known

specialist.correctSentence: I resent your saying that
Imagine being rich
We discussed going
He mentioned seeing her
I suggest leaving
She appears to be crying
I failed to reach him
He managed to escape
We tend to forget
I anticipate arriving

master.correctSentence: There's no point in arguing
I object to going
He confessed to stealing
She is committed to helping

master.original: We should focus on to win.
master.correctSentence: We should focus on winning
It resulted in losing
I succeeded in fixing it
He insisted on paying
We apologize for being late
She dreams of traveling

c1_compound_relative.title: Compound Relative Clauses
c1_compound_relative.subtitle: Whoever, Whatever, Whenever, etc.
c1_compound_relative.quickLesson:
⚡ Compound Relatives

1. Whoever: The person who / Anyone who.

2. Whatever: The thing that / Anything that.

3. Whenever: At any time.

explorer.original: Any place you go, I follow.
Any way you do it is fine.
explorer.correctSentence: However you do it is fine

explorer.original: The person who stole it ran.

scholar.correctSentence: Whatever happens stay

scholar.original: No matter who calls, don't answer.
scholar.correctSentence: Whoever calls don't answer

scholar.original: No matter when you arrive, call.
scholar.correctSentence: Whenever you arrive call

scholar.original: No matter where he is, I'll find him.
scholar.correctSentence: Wherever he is I'll find him

scholar.original: No matter how hard it is, try.
scholar.correctSentence: However hard it is try

scholar.original: No matter which you pick, it's good.
scholar.correctSentence: Whichever you pick it's good
Ask whoever you see
Eat whatever you like
Sleep whenever you can
Sit wherever you like

specialist.correctSentence: I will pay whatever the price
Whoever said that is lying
Choose whichever path you want

specialist.original: However fast he runs, he loses.
specialist.correctSentence: However fast he runs he loses
Whenever she calls I am busy

specialist.original: Wherever you hide, I see you.
specialist.correctSentence: Wherever you hide I see you
Whoever wins gets a prize
Whatever happens just smile
Whichever day you choose is fine

specialist.original: However you fix it, do it.
specialist.correctSentence: However you fix it just do it

master.correctSentence: Whatever the cost may be buy it

master.original: Whoever he is, he is rude.
master.correctSentence: Whoever he may be he is rude

master.original: However rich he is, he is sad.
master.correctSentence: However rich he may be he is sad

master.original: Wherever it is, I want it.
master.correctSentence: Wherever it may be I want it
Whenever it is possible come
Whichever way we go we lose
Whatever he might say ignore it
Whoever might ask say nothing
However much it costs pay it
Wherever we find ourselves we fight

c1_wish_if_only.title: Wish & If Only
c1_wish_if_only.subtitle: Expressing regrets and desires.
c1_wish_if_only.quickLesson:
⚡ Wish / If Only

1. Present Regret: I wish I knew. (Past Simple)

2. Past Regret: If only I had known. (Past Perfect)

3. Complaint: I wish you would stop. (Would)

explorer.correctSentence: I wish I hadn't eaten that
I wish you would stop shouting
I wish I had a car
If only I hadn't missed the party
I wish he weren't so loud

scholar.correctSentence: I wish I were taller
I wish I hadn't slept late
I wish you would listen to me
If only I hadn't lost my keys
I wish I didn't have to work
I wish they wouldn't argue
If only it weren't so cold
I wish I had studied
I wish he would smoke less
If only I weren't so busy

specialist.correctSentence: I wish I hadn't bought this car
If only you wouldn't interrupt me
I wish I lived in the country
If only I had brought a coat
I wish he would help sometimes
If only I could speak French
I wish she weren't angry
I wish I hadn't sold my bike
If only it would stop raining
I wish I knew the answer

master.correctSentence: I wish I had applied for the job
If only you would stop tapping your pen
I wish I could take back my words
If only he weren't so stubborn
I wish we had caught the train
I wish you wouldn't complain so much
If only I had more time
I wish I hadn't made that mistake
I wish she weren't leaving so soon
If only I were brave enough

c1_subjunctive.title: Subjunctive Mood
c1_subjunctive.subtitle: Hypothetical situations and demands.
c1_subjunctive.quickLesson:
⚡ Subjunctive

1. Demand: I insist that he [study]. (Base form)

2. Hypothetical: If I [were] you. (Were for all persons)

3. Fixed Phrases: Be that as it may.

explorer.correctSentence: It is important that she go

explorer.original: It is necessary he is here.
explorer.correctSentence: It is necessary that he be here

scholar.correctSentence: The judge ordered that he stand
It is vital that she know
Recommends that he go
If she were rich
Urgent that he help
Propose that she join
Crucial that he see it
Prefer that she speak
Mandatory that he attend
If it were true

specialist.correctSentence: God save the Queen
Be that as it may
Come what may
Suffice it to say
Far be it from me
If need be
So be it
Long live the King
Heaven forbid
Truth be told

master.correctSentence: Whatever be the outcome
Cost what it may
I insist that he be removed
Whether it be true or false
Unless he pay his debts
Lest he forget
Though he be poor
Till death do us part
Unless I be mistaken

master.original: It is essential the work finishes.
master.correctSentence: It is essential the work be finished
master.hint: It is essential the work be...
